#Text=Thomé Lopes
#Text=Thomé Lopes
#Text=( sometimes modernized as Tomé Lopes ) was a Portuguese scrivener , writer of an eyewitness account of the second journey of Vasco da Gama to India ( 1502 – 1503 ) .
#Text=Thomé Lopes 's background is obscure .
#Text=All that is known is that he was a native of Porto , Portugal .

#Text=In early 1502 , Thomé Lopes was hired as a escrivão ( captain 's clerk ) aboard an unnamed ship owned and outfitted by Ruy Mendes de Brito [ 1 ] ( a gentleman of the royal chamber of King Manuel I of Portugal [ 2 ] ) and captained by an Italian , Giovanni Buonagratia ( João de Buonagracia ) of Florence . [ 3 ]
#Text=This ship was part of a Portuguese squadron of five ships , under the overall command of Estêvão da Gama ( cousin of Vasco da Gama ) .

#Text=This squadron set out from Lisbon on 1 April 1502 , intending to catch up and join the 4th Portuguese India Armada of admiral Vasco da Gama , which had left a few months earlier ( February 1502 ) .
#Text=According to Lopes , their squadron caught up with the main armada on 21 August 1502 at Anjediva Island , off the Malabar Coast of India . [ 4 ]

#Text=Among the most memorable passages in Lopes 's account , is a detailed description of the notorious massacre of the Muslim pilgrim ships ( 3 October 1502 a day " that I remember every day of my life " [ 5 ] ) on the orders of Vasco da Gama .
#Text=Later Portuguese chroniclers have dealt uneasily with this act of cruelty , but Lopes 's vivid and often heart-breaking narrative leaves little unmentioned .

#Text=Another famous episode reported by Lopes is the execution by impaling of three Muslims in Cochin , on the orders of the Trimumpara Raja , the Hindu prince of Cochin , for the sacrilege of selling a cow for beef to the crew of a Portuguese ship in harbor .

#Text=It is notable that it was admiral Vasco da Gama himself ( not usually known for his cultural sensitivity ) who arrested the three men and handed them over to the Cochinese authorities for justice , and forbade any further purchases of cows by Portuguese sailors . [ 6 ]
#Text=Lopes and the armada left India in February 1503 , beginning its return journey back to Portugal .
#Text=Lopes reports how his ship was nearly sunk in a collision with another off Mozambique Island . [ 7 ]
#Text=Somewhere around the Cape of Good Hope in July , Lopes reports an encounter with two of the ships of the outgoing 5th Armada of Afonso de Albuquerque . [ 8 ]
#Text=On 30 July 1503 Thomé Lopes 's ship , accompanied by two others , came across and landed on the South Atlantic island of Saint Helena .
#Text=Lopes refers to it as an unknown island , [ 9 ] and gives its position relative to Ascension Island ( which he refers to by that name [ 10 ] ) .

#Text=It is commonly accepted that Ascension island was first discovered in May 1501 on the outward journey of João da Nova , and some writers [ 11 ] have questioned how Lopes could have known about that island as he left Lisbon before Nova 's fleet returned .
#Text=A clue is given in Lopes 's own account , where he describes how , in August 1502 , they picked up letters in Malindi left by the returning João da Nova . [ 12 ]
#Text=These letters might have described Nova 's discovery of Ascension island on the outward journey ( although not , of course , Nova 's own discovery of Saint Helena on his return in May 1502 ) .

#Text=The only quibble remains with Lopes 's use of the name " Ascension " island , as it is commonly thought Nova originally named it Conceição ( Conception island ) , and it was only renamed " Ascension " later ( May 1503 ) by Afonso de Albuquerque .

column1: #Text=One possible explanation is that Lopes 's account might not have been written immediately in 1502 , but a little later after his arrival in Portugal , after the name of Ascension island had already been settled upon . [ 13 ]

#Text=But the most probable explanation is simply that the name ( and maybe even the locational information ) was reported to Thomé Lopes precisely by the two 5th Armada ships that , as already mentioned , Lopes just encountered near the Cape of Good Hope ( the two would have been coming precisely from Albuquerque 's ( re-)discovery of Ascension island ) .

#Text=The original Portuguese version of Thomé Lopes 's account has been lost , but an Italian translation was published in 1550 in Venice , in a collection of travelogues collected by Giovanni Battista Ramusio .
#Text=A translation back to Portuguese was commissioned and published in 1812 .
#Text=Thomé Lopes 's account is one of several eyewitness account of the 4th Portuguese India Armada of 1502-03 .
#Text=It is widely regarded as reliable , and frequently resorted to by historians to correct the accounts by later 16th-century chroniclers ( João de Barros , Gaspar Correia , etc. )
